Improve user flows through design and information architecture refinement to reduce pain points and enable users to identify and complete objectives faster—less mistakes/confusion/abandonment.
Improve the overall “look and feel” to create a more consistent visual language that prioritizes modern aesthetics (more images and micro-interactions, less “walls of text” and link-driven pathways).
Prioritize prominent CTAs for quick recognition to drive completion of user and business objectives.
Reduce design debt site-wide to improve the overall user experience and design consistency and efficiency.

is a release strategy that uses two identical environments—one live (Blue) and one idle (Green). New updates are deployed to the idle environment, where they’re validated without impacting users. Once testing is complete, traffic is seamlessly switched to the updated environment, minimizing downtime and enabling quick rollback if needed.

Modernize deployments by doing a discovery on best approach to do content sync from the pipeline before UAT starts to ensure we are UAT with the latest content from PROD. This would also include functions/triggers to have nightly deployments to QA environments to improve efficiency by not having to wait 1-3hrs during the day and not impact any CSL testing during the day

column2: WinWatcher re-write to pull from API for game data and discontinue file drops for game data
column3: WinWatcher was built pre 2020 and has a lot of bad/unused code and does not utilize cache. The goal here would be to re-write the WW code to be able to handle errors better, not cause as many DB cleanup task, and to utilize Redis cache once a file is processed correctly, which would improve performance on PWS for features that rely on WW data

column3: Move away from in memory caching and utilize Redis to have an easier way to share cached data between different applications, like WW, Retailer Service, and PWS. This work also includes revisiting the timing of the draw games cache to be more inline when files drop vs every 1-2 minutes, as well as getting the new cache enhancements to prod that done late last year. This project would increase performance and reduce db utilization, which would in turn reduce the need to scale up the db as frequently as we do now.

Improve secure coding standards, reducing both security and coding technical debt while enhancing developer efficiency and confidence.
By embedding secure-by-design principles, standardized code review practices, and automated vulnerability detection into our development lifecycle, we not only protect our products and clients — we also empower developers with cleaner, more maintainable code.
Improving security at the coding level helps developers by reducing rework, simplifying future integrations, and providing clearer guardrails for safe innovation. This approach strengthens client trust, accelerates delivery timelines, and establishes a foundation that allows us to innovate securely and sustainably.

Currently the load testing is a manual process that requires heavy configurations that relies on a java framework called JMeter. While we still may convert the new load testing framework to JMeter or another Azure Load Testing framework called Locust, we would like to move to a more modern approach to use a JavaScript framework, something like K6 or Artillery. We would be integrating this directly into the CI/CD pipeline to run on each deployment, ensuring site performance is being closely tracked with each release. With a new JS framework, this would allow QA to own load testing updates during their test case creation.

k6 is lightweight, CLI-driven, and emphasizes developer-friendly workflows, making it comparable to JMeter for load and performance testing without the overhead of a full GUI.

Mature foundational security practices across our products and platforms — reducing technical security debt, strengthening client trust, and enabling future innovation.By standardizing secure design principles, embedding risk-informed controls, and addressing legacy vulnerabilities, we can build a resilient foundation that not only meets compliance expectations but also positions security as a business enabler. This transformation will allow us to deliver with confidence, accelerate new feature adoption, and open doors for innovation in a secure and scalable way.
